title: Quiz 3: The Upper Limb
description: In-depth review of the upper limb anatomy, including the brachial plexus, axilla, shoulder, arm, forearm, hand, and relevant nerve injuries.

questions.question: Arrange the segments of the Brachial Plexus from proximal (neck) to distal (axilla):
questions.explanation: The Brachial Plexus is organized as: Roots (C5-T1) -> Trunks (Upper/Middle/Lower) -> Divisions (Ant/Post) -> Cords (Lat/Med/Post) -> Branches (Nerves). Mnemonic: 'Real Texans Drink Cold Beer'.
questions.hint: Remember the mnemonic: Real Texans Drink Cold Beer.

questions.question: A patient falls on an outstretched hand and presents with tenderness in the 'anatomical snuffbox'. Which bone is most likely fractured?
questions.explanation: The Scaphoid forms the floor of the anatomical snuffbox. Fractures here are common and carry a risk of avascular necrosis because the blood supply enters distally.
questions.hint: It is the most commonly fractured carpal bone.

questions.question: Match the specific nerve injury with the resulting clinical deformity:
questions.explanation: Erb's = Waiter's tip (loss of abductors/lateral rotators). Klumpke's = Claw hand (loss of intrinsic muscles). Radial = Wrist drop (loss of extensors). Long Thoracic = Winging (loss of Serratus Anterior).
questions.hint: Match the location of injury to the functional loss.

questions.question: Which of the following structures pierce the Clavipectoral Fascia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Structures piercing clavipectoral fascia: Cephalic vein, Thoracoacromial artery, Lateral pectoral nerve, and Lymphatics.
questions.hint: Think about structures entering or leaving the pectoral region superiorly.

questions.question: Which muscle is the primary initiator of shoulder abduction (first 15 degrees)?
questions.explanation: Supraspinatus initiates abduction (0-15 degrees). The Deltoid takes over from 15-90 degrees. Trapezius/Serratus Anterior allow abduction >90 degrees by rotating the scapula.
questions.hint: It is part of the rotator cuff located superiorly.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ nerve and the ___BLANK___ artery pass through the Quadrangular Space.
questions.explanation: The Quadrangular space transmits the Axillary nerve and the Posterior Circumflex Humeral artery.
questions.hint: The nerve supplies the deltoid; the artery winds around the surgical neck.

questions.question: Review the table below regarding forearm muscles. Which muscle is supplied by the Ulnar Nerve?

richContent.content:
MuscleCompartmentPrimary Action
Flexor Carpi RadialisAnteriorFlex/Abduct Wrist
Flexor Carpi UlnarisAnteriorFlex/Adduct Wrist
Pronator TeresAnteriorPronation

questions.explanation: Most anterior forearm muscles are supplied by the Median nerve. The exceptions are Flexor Carpi Ulnaris (FCU) and the medial half of Flexor Digitorum Profundus (FDP), which are supplied by the Ulnar nerve.
questions.hint: It is the muscle on the medial side of the forearm.

questions.question: The median nerve passes between the two heads of the Pronator Teres muscle.
questions.explanation: TRUE. The median nerve passes between the humeral and ulnar heads of the Pronator Teres. This is a potential site for nerve entrapment (Pronator Syndrome).
questions.hint: This relationship is characteristic in the proximal forearm.

questions.question: Which of the following form the boundaries of the Cubital Fossa? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Cubital Fossa: Roof = Fascia/Bicipital aponeurosis. Floor = Brachialis/Supinator. Medial = Pronator Teres. Lateral = Brachioradialis. Superior = Interepicondylar line.
questions.hint: Think of the triangle in front of the elbow.

questions.question: Which nerve travels in the spiral groove of the humerus along with the profunda brachii artery?
questions.explanation: The radial nerve and profunda brachii vessels travel in the spiral groove on the posterior aspect of the humerus.
questions.hint: Damage here causes wrist drop.

questions.question: Match the intrinsic hand muscle group with its nerve supply:
questions.explanation: Median Nerve supplies 'LOAF': Lateral 2 Lumbricals, Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, Flexor pollicis brevis. All other intrinsic muscles are Ulnar.
questions.hint: Remember LOAF for Median nerve.

questions.question: Which tendon serves as the medial border of the anatomical snuffbox?
questions.explanation: The snuffbox is bounded laterally by APL and EPB, and medially by the Extensor Pollicis Longus (EPL) tendon.
questions.hint: It is the tendon that sticks out most when you extend your thumb like a hitchhiker.

questions.question: What is the action of the Dorsal Interossei muscles?
questions.explanation: DAB: Dorsal Abduct. PAD: Palmar Adduct. Both sets also flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints.
questions.hint: Remember the acronym DAB.

questions.question: Order the contents of the Cubital Fossa from Medial to Lateral:
questions.explanation: M-B-B-R: Median nerve, Brachial artery, Biceps tendon, Radial nerve (from Medial to Lateral).
questions.hint: My Bottom Beats Red (Medial to Lateral).

questions.question: Which of the following are branches of the Axillary Artery? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Branches: 1st part (Superior thoracic); 2nd part (Thoracoacromial, Lateral thoracic); 3rd part (Subscapular, Ant/Post circumflex humeral). Brachial is the continuation, not a branch.
questions.hint: Screw The Lawyer, Save A Patient (Mnemonic).

questions.question: The axillary lymph nodes receive approximately 75% of the lymph from the breast.
questions.explanation: TRUE. The axillary nodes (specifically the Anterior/Pectoral group) are the primary drainage site for the breast, making them a critical site for metastasis.
questions.hint: This is why axillary clearance is done for breast cancer.

questions.question: Which specific condition results from the thickening and contracture of the palmar aponeurosis, causing flexion deformity of the fingers?
questions.explanation: Dupuytren's contracture affects the medial side of the palmar aponeurosis, usually pulling the ring and little fingers into flexion.
questions.hint: Named after a French surgeon.

questions.question: The pulsation of the Radial Artery is best felt:

options.text: Medial to the Flexor Carpi Ulnaris tendon
Lateral to the Flexor Carpi Radialis tendon
Medial to the Palmaris Longus tendon

questions.explanation: The radial pulse is felt at the wrist lateral to the tendon of Flexor Carpi Radialis, against the distal radius.
questions.hint: Lateral to the most lateral flexor tendon at the wrist.

questions.question: Which cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the Ulnar nerve?
questions.explanation: The Medial Cord gives rise to the Ulnar nerve, Medial pectoral nerve, and Cutaneous nerves of arm/forearm. The Median nerve is formed by Lateral + Medial cords.
questions.hint: It runs on the medial side of the arm.

questions.question: Match the arm muscle with its nerve supply:
questions.explanation: Anterior compartment (Flexors) = Musculocutaneous. Posterior compartment (Extensors) = Radial.
questions.hint: Front vs Back of arm.

questions.question: What structure forms the roof of the Carpal Tunnel?
questions.explanation: The Flexor Retinaculum (Transverse Carpal Ligament) forms the roof. The carpal bones form the floor and sides.
questions.hint: A strong fibrous band crossing the wrist anteriorly.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ vein runs up the lateral side of the arm and lies in the deltopectoral groove.
questions.explanation: The Cephalic vein is lateral (Up towards the head/Cephalic). The Basilic vein is medial.
questions.hint: Lateral vein.

questions.question: Damage to the radial nerve in the axilla (e.g., crutch palsy) results in:

options.text: Loss of elbow extension and wrist drop

questions.explanation: Damage in the axilla affects the nerve BEFORE it supplies the Triceps. Thus, extension of the elbow is lost, along with extension of the wrist (wrist drop). Mid-shaft fractures spare the triceps.
questions.hint: The injury is very proximal, affecting the triceps.

questions.question: Order the proximal row of carpal bones from Lateral to Medial:
questions.explanation: Proximal Row (Lat -> Med): Scaphoid, Lunate, Triquetrum, Pisiform. (Mnemonic: She Looks Too Pretty).
questions.hint: Start with the bone in the snuffbox.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of an Ulnar nerve lesion at the wrist? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Claw hand (hyperextension of MCP, flexion of IP joints of ring/little finger)
Loss of sensation over the thenar eminence

questions.explanation: Ulnar nerve lesion causes Claw Hand (medial 2 fingers), Hypothenar wasting, and Interossei wasting (Froment's sign +). Thenar sensation is Median. Wrist drop is Radial.
questions.hint: Think about the intrinsic muscles the ulnar nerve supplies.
